Granting Access Rights at the View Level

Usually, granting access rights at the project level is not a fine enough level of granularity. For example, one set of developers might maintain Release 1.0 of a product in one view, while another set of developers write the source code for Release 2.0 in another view.

When you set view access rights, these rights are for the current view. The rights on the View node are also available from the View node in the Project Access Rights dialog. In the latter case, the rights cover all the views in the project rather than an individual view. The Project Access Rights dialog also includes a container-level right that allows users or groups to create views for the project.

A user will not be able to open a particular project view if you deny that user (or all the groups to which he or she belongs) any of the following:

  • The ability to see that view.

  • The ability to see that view’s root folder.

A child view and its parent view are represented different objects in the repository. The child view has a different name, description, place in the view hierarchy, etc. Initially, it has no access rights at the view level, but you can set access rights for this view, just as you can for the parent.

General Rule

Any time you create one grant record for a node, you should also create a grant record for that node for every group that will access the project at this level. It is also a good idea to include Administrators on each node. Then if permissions are ignored, an administrator can still change access rights, etc.

To set view access rights:

  1. Open the view.

  2. Select View > Access  Rights from the StarTeam client menu. This action displays the View Access Rights dialog.

  3. Select the View node.

  4. From the Access Rights dialog, click Add to add a user or group. The Assign Access Rights To dialog opens.

  5. Select a user or group. Users are listed by their user names and groups are listed by their position in the group hierarchy, except for the All Users group.

  6. Select the Grant option button. Note: Never select the Deny option button unless you are creating an exception. See Setting Access Rights Exceptions.

  7. Click OK to return to the View Access Rights dialog.

  8. Select and/or clear the appropriate check boxes for the user or group.

  9. Repeat steps 3-8 as required.

  10. Click OK when you are done.

View Access Rights

See object and its properties

See this view in the views list, and review its properties by selecting View > Properties.

Modify properties

Change the properties for this view. The view properties that can be modified are the view’s name, description, working folder (which is also the working folder for the root folder), branch setting for shared items, and file status repository setting.

Delete object

Delete this view from the project.

Change object access rights

Change the access rights for this view. If you change this setting, be sure that you remain one of the users who can change access rights.

Create view labels

Create view labels for this view. Creating view labels automatically attaches them to the folders and items in the view. Users with this right but not the right to attach view labels can still create view labels.

Modify view labels

Change the properties of view labels for this view. For example, this right allows a user to freeze and unfreeze labels.

Delete view labels

Delete view labels from this view. Deleting view labels automatically detaches them from the folders and items that had those labels. Users with this right but not the right to detach view labels can still delete view labels.

Create revision labels

Create revision labels for this view. Users with this right but not the right to attach revision labels can still create revision labels.

Modify revision labels

Change the properties of revision labels for this view. For example, this right allows a user to freeze and unfreeze labels.

Delete revision labels

Delete revision labels from this view. Deleting revision labels automatically detaches them from the folders and items that had those labels.  Users with this right but not the right to detach revision labels can still delete revision labels.

Define promotion model

Create, delete, edit, and reorder promotion states. After creating a promotion state, you must exit and re-enter the Promotion dialog if you want to set access rights for the newly created state.

Create views

Create views in the current project. This container-level right is available only when you select Project > Access Rights followed by the View node.
